bioghist.p: Donald Maxwell Matthews, born June 29, 1886, graduated from the University of Michigan (B.A. 1908; M.S. in forestry, 1909). After graduation, he went to the Philippines where he was a forester with the Philippine Bureau of Forestry (1909-1914) and a professor of forestry at the University of the Philippines (1910-1914). From 1914 to 1920, Matthews was conservator of forests for the Government of British North Borneo. From 1920 to 1925, he was manager of the British Borneo Timber Company, then went to Washington D.C. as forester with the U.S. Tropical Plant Research Bureau. Matthews came to the University of Michigan in 1927 as professor of forest management. That same year, Matthews accepted an offer from the United Fruit Company and the Compania Cubana to go to Cuba and organize and direct the work of reforesting large areas of land owned by these company which were determined not suitable for the production of sugar. In 1930, Matthews helped to organize the Brazilian forest Service. He died September 14, 1948.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of a single series of photographs, arranged alphabetically by place name or by topic. Most of the images detail forestry practices in Central and South America and the sugar cane industry in Cuba and other Caribbean islands. Some of the photographs relate to forestry in Louisiana and South Carolina.
